rule.name: Container Image - Package with Critical Severity CVEs
rule.logic: Package where scannedAsset.entityType in('KubernetesImage', 'ContainerRegistryImage', 'ShiftLeftImage', 'EcsImage') should not have severity='Critical'
rule.description: Container Image contains Package with Critical Severity CVEs
rule.remediation: Check the Remediation field on the Package. If there is a Remediation, upgrade the package to the recommended package version.

rule.name: Container Image - Package with High Severity CVEs
rule.logic: Package where scannedAsset.entityType in('KubernetesImage', 'ContainerRegistryImage', 'ShiftLeftImage', 'EcsImage') should not have severity='High'
rule.description: Container Image contains Package with High Severity CVEs
rule.remediation: Check the Remediation field on the Package. If there is a Remediation, upgrade the package to the recommended package version.

rule.name: AWS Workloads - Package with Critical Severity CVEs
rule.logic: Package where scannedAsset.entityType='Instance' should not have severity='Critical'
rule.description: Aws Instance contains Package with Critical Severity CVEs
rule.remediation: Check the Remediation field on the Package. If there is a Remediation, upgrade the package to the recommended package version.

rule.name: Azure Workloads - Package with Critical Severity CVEs
rule.logic: Package where scannedAsset.entityType in('FunctionApp', 'VirtualMachine') should not have severity='Critical'
rule.description: Azure Virtual Machine or Function App contains Package with Critical Severity CVEs
rule.remediation: Check the Remediation field on the Package. If there is a Remediation, upgrade the package to the recommended package version.

rule.name: Azure Workloads - Package with High Severity CVEs
rule.logic: Package where scannedAsset.entityType in('FunctionApp', 'VirtualMachine') should not have severity='High'
rule.description: Azure Virtual Machine or Function App contains Package with High Severity CVEs
rule.remediation: Check the Remediation field on the Package. If there is a Remediation, upgrade the package to the recommended package version.

rule.name: AWS Workloads - Malware
rule.description: AWS Instance contains malware (malicious IP, URL or file)
rule.remediation: Take proactive measures to thoroughly investigate and address the detected malware, and remove it from your application if necessary.

rule.name: Container Image - Malware
rule.logic: Malware where scannedAsset.entityType in('KubernetesImage', 'ContainerRegistryImage', 'ShiftLeftImage', 'EcsImage') should fail
rule.description: Container Image contains malware (malicious IP, URL or file)
rule.remediation: Take proactive measures to thoroughly investigate and address the detected malware, and remove it from your application if necessary.

rule.name: AWS Workloads - Package with High Severity CVEs
rule.logic: Package where scannedAsset.entityType='Instance' should not have severity='High'
rule.description: Aws Instance contains Package with High Severity CVEs
rule.remediation: Check the Remediation field on the Package. If there is a Remediation, upgrade the package to the recommended package version.

rule.name: Azure Workloads - Malware
rule.logic: Malware where scannedAsset.entityType in('FunctionApp', 'VirtualMachine') should fail
rule.description: Azure Virtual Machine or Function App contains malware (malicious IP, URL or file)
rule.remediation: Take proactive measures to thoroughly investigate and address the detected malware, and remove it from your application if necessary.

rule.name: Azure Workloads – Insecure Content
rule.logic: InsecureContent where scannedAsset.entityType in('FunctionApp', 'VirtualMachine') should fail
rule.description: Azure Virtual Machine or Function App contains insecure content (e.g., secrets or credentials)
rule.remediation: Conduct a comprehensive review of your application code to assess the nature of the identified data. Implement security measures to mitigate the risk associated with insecure content

rule.name: AWS Workloads – Insecure Content
rule.description: AWS Instance contains insecure content (e.g., secrets or credentials)
rule.remediation: Conduct a comprehensive review of your application code to assess the nature of the identified data. Implement security measures to mitigate the risk associated with insecure content

rule.name: Container Image – Insecure Content
rule.logic: InsecureContent where scannedAsset.entityType in('KubernetesImage', 'ContainerRegistryImage', 'ShiftLeftImage', 'EcsImage') should fail
rule.description: Container Image contains insecure content (e.g., secrets or credentials)
rule.remediation: Conduct a comprehensive review of your application code to assess the nature of the identified data. Implement security measures to mitigate the risk associated with insecure content

cves.description: MiniZip in zlib through 1.3 has an integer overflow and resultant heap-based buffer overflow in zipOpenNewFileInZip4_64 via a long filename, comment, or extra field. NOTE: MiniZip is not a supported part of the zlib product. NOTE: pyminizip through 0.2.6 is also vulnerable because it bundles an affected zlib version, and exposes the applicable MiniZip code through its compress API.

relatedCves.description: MiniZip in zlib through 1.3 has an integer overflow and resultant heap-based buffer overflow in zipOpenNewFileInZip4_64 via a long filename, comment, or extra field. NOTE: MiniZip is not a supported part of the zlib product. NOTE: pyminizip through 0.2.6 is also vulnerable because it bundles an affected zlib version, and exposes the applicable MiniZip code through its compress API.

cves.description: A flaw was found in shadow-utils. When asking for a new password, shadow-utils asks the password twice. If the password fails on the second attempt, shadow-utils fails in cleaning the buffer used to store the first entry. This may allow an attacker with enough access to retrieve the password from the memory.

In Shadow 4.13, it is possible to inject control characters into fields provided to the SUID program chfn (change finger). Although it is not possible to exploit this directly (e.g., adding a new user fails because \n is in the block list), it is possible to misrepresent the /etc/passwd file when viewed. Use of \r manipulations and Unicode characters to work around blocking of the : character make it possible to give the impression that a new user has been added. In other words, an adversary may be able to convince a system administrator to take the system offline (an indirect, social-engineered denial of service) by demonstrating that "cat /etc/passwd" shows a rogue user account.

relatedCves.description: A flaw was found in shadow-utils. When asking for a new password, shadow-utils asks the password twice. If the password fails on the second attempt, shadow-utils fails in cleaning the buffer used to store the first entry. This may allow an attacker with enough access to retrieve the password from the memory.

A flaw was found in shadow-utils. When asking for a new password, shadow-utils asks the password twice. If the password fails on the second attempt, shadow-utils fails in cleaning the buffer used to store the first entry. This may allow an attacker with enough access to retrieve the password from the memory.

In Shadow 4.13, it is possible to inject control characters into fields provided to the SUID program chfn (change finger). Although it is not possible to exploit this directly (e.g., adding a new user fails because \n is in the block list), it is possible to misrepresent the /etc/passwd file when viewed. Use of \r manipulations and Unicode characters to work around blocking of the : character make it possible to give the impression that a new user has been added. In other words, an adversary may be able to convince a system administrator to take the system offline (an indirect, social-engineered denial of service) by demonstrating that "cat /etc/passwd" shows a rogue user account.

cves.description: **DISPUTED**A failure in the -fstack-protector feature in GCC-based toolchains  that target AArch64 allows an attacker to exploit an existing buffer  overflow in dynamically-sized local variables in your application  without this being detected. This stack-protector failure only applies  to C99-style dynamically-sized local variables or those created using  alloca(). The stack-protector operates as intended for statically-sized  local variables.  The default behavior when the stack-protector  detects an overflow is to terminate your application, resulting in  controlled loss of availability. An attacker who can exploit a buffer  overflow without triggering the stack-protector might be able to change  program flow control to cause an uncontrolled loss of availability or to  go further and affect confidentiality or integrity. NOTE: The GCC project argues that this is a missed hardening bug and not a vulnerability by itself.

relatedCves.description:
